title: Question 44

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for painful genital ulcers that began 2 days ago. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with primary genital herpes simplex virus type 2 but has not had a recurrence since then. The patient has not been sexually active for the past year. She takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The left inguinal lymph nodes are palpable and tender. Three ulcerated lesions are present on the inner aspect of the left labia majora. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Treatment with valacyclovir, acyclovir, or famciclovir is appropriate for patients with a history of genital ulcer disease caused by herpes simplex virus type 2 and clinical findings consistent with recurrent genital herpes.
Treatment with valacyclovir is most appropriate for this patient (

). She has a history of genital ulcer disease caused by herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) and has clinical findings consistent with recurrent genital herpes, so she should be provided with antiviral therapy. Reconfirmation of the diagnosis in the setting of a consistent clinical presentation is not necessary. Valacyclovir, acyclovir, and famciclovir are all acceptable antiviral regimens for management of recurrent genital HSV and will shorten the duration of this episode. Antiviral therapy for recurrent infection is recommended within 1 day of lesion onset or at the onset of prodromal symptoms. Regardless of the antiviral agent used, treatment regimens for recurrent genital HSV are short (2-5 days). The patient should be counseled that she may experience subsequent recurrences, and she can be provided with a prescription for antiviral therapy to begin immediately if she experiences another recurrence. Long-term suppressive therapy is an option if she experiences frequent subsequent recurrences or if she desires to reduce the potential for transmission to a future sexual partner who does not have HSV-2 infection. She should be counseled regarding the importance of informing future sexual partners of her diagnosis and the potential for viral shedding and transmission even without active lesions. HSV-2 seropositive persons are at increased risk for HIV acquisition, so the importance of condoms should be stressed.
